summary.seg: This manuscript contains a collection of Byzantine canonical texts, comprising the works of Matthew Blastares, canonist and theologian of the 14th century.
The codex is formed of two parts.

The principal one (I: ff. [ii] recto-160v), containing the canonical texts, was copied by the scribe Ignatios, who signed the manuscript on 19th June 1574. The second part (II: ff. 161r-185v) was written by another contemporary hand and contains an incomplete index of subjects in the Scripture.

Ff.3.4, together with another Greek manuscript,
CUL Ff.3.30 , was donated on 16th July 1650 by the English merchant Edward Abbott, at the time consul at Cairo, to Nicholas Hobart (ca. 1605-1657), Fellow of King's College in Cambridge (1624-1650). Hobart donated the codices to Cambridge University Library a few years later, in 1655.

supportDesc.foliation: The leaves are foliated 1-160 in brown ink, in Arabic numerals, in the upper margin, right. The number 27 has been assigned to two leaves ( f. 27r and f. 27[a]r ). Due to a missing quire, the foliation skips from 47 to 56; on f. 47r the number 55 has been added to the folio number: 47=55. The folio number 91 is not present. Leaves 161 to 185 have a foliation in modern pencil, in Arabic numerals, on the top right hand corner recto; the numbers 161, 171 and 185 are repeated on the lower right corner recto of the leaves. [i]-[ii] + 1-27, 27[a], 28-47, 56-90, 92-185 + [iii].
supportDesc.condition: The manuscript is in fair condition. The leaves are yellowed and, throughout the manuscript, there are numerous humidity and brown stains, see e.g. ff. 1r-1v, 8r-8v, 113r, 120v, 185v. The black ink of the second part of the manuscript has smudged leaving black stains, see e.g. ff. 172v-173r, ff. 178v-179r. There are tears on various leaves, see e.g. f. 1v, where two tears were fixed with paper strips, ff. 3r-3v, ff. 160r-160v.

binding.p: Modern western binding. Paper cover over couched-laminate boards, leather on spine. On the spine gold tooling with title on red square, Greek Church M.S., and leather labels with classmark.

history.provenance:
The codex was in the hands of the English merchant Edward Abbott, consul at Cairo in the 1650s (concerning him see Oates (1986), pp. 292-294 with bibliography), who donated it to
Hobart, Nicholas, approximately 1605-1657 Nicholas Hobart (ca. 1605-1657) , Fellow of King's College in Cambridge from 1625 to 1650. This is stated in a message from Abbott to Hobart written on f. [ii] verso, dated 16th July 1650 in Cairo: nÂº 2. Sir, this manuscript composed by Theodoro Ballamone of the Rites and Ceremonyes of the Greek church, hath some curiosityes in it, yet is not so perfect as I should have wished, however I desyre your acceptance of it, being the best that could heer be found, by your most affectionate servant Edw. Abbott. Grand Cayro, the 16th July 1650.. The wrong name (and spelling) of the author derives from an annotation in Greek on f. [ii] recto citing Theodor Balsamon. The wrong name was underlined and corrected by another hand as Matthaeus Blasteres.
history.acquisition: The manuscript was donated to Cambridge University Library by Nicholas Hobart, as it is stated also in a note on a paper strip pasted on the lower part of f. [ii] verso, Ex dono ornatissimi viri Nicolai Hobart Collegii Regalis quondam socii et huius Academiae insignis ornamenti. 1655. On the same folio is pasted the Cambridge University bookplate.

recordHist.source: Description (2020) draws partly on A catalogue of the Manuscripts preserved in the Library of the University of Cambridge, vol. 2: Ee-Ff, Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, 1857, pp. 411-412.

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library). For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.

msItem.author: Johannes Citri Episcopus
msItem.title: Responsa ad Constantinum Cabasilam episcopum
msItem.note:
The manuscript contains the recension by
Blastares, Matthew, active 14th century Matthew Blastares , which is comprised in his work Collectio alphabetica (TLG 3237.001, ed. Rhalles-Potles 6 (1856), from p. 80 l. 27), which comprises answers by Johannes of Kitros and texts by Theodore Balsamon, see J. DarrouzÃ¨s, 'Les rÃ©ponses canoniques de Jean de Kitros', in: Revue des Ã©tudes byzantines 31 (1973), pp. 319-334: esp. pp. 332-334 with the list of incipits and reference to the printed editions

msItem.title: Colophon
msItem.colophon: f. 160v ll. 25-27 Î¤á¿· Î´á½² Î¸Îµá¿· á¼¡Î¼á¿¶Î½, Ïá¿· Î´ÏÏÎ®ÏÎ¹ Ïá¿¶Î½ á¼Î³Î±Î¸á¿¶Î½, ÏÏÎ­ÏÎµÎ¹ Î´ÏÎ¾Î±Î ÎºÏÎ¬ÏÎ¿Ï ÏÎ¹Î¼á½´ ÎºÎ±á½¶ ÏÏÎ¿ÏÎºÏÎ½Î·ÏÎ¹Ï, Îºá¾Î¼Î¿á½¶ ÏÎ±Ïá½° ÏÎ¸Î¬ÏÎ±Î½ÏÎ¹ ÏÎ­ÏÎ¼Î± Ïá¿Ï Î²Î¯Î²Î»Î¿Ï . á¼Î½ á¼ÏÎµÎ¹ á¼Ïá½¸ Ïá¿Ï á¼Î½ ÏÎ¬ÏÎºÎµÎ¹ Î¿á¼°ÎºÎ¿Î½Î¿Î¼Î¯Î±Ï ÍµÎ±ÏÎ¿Î´Î á¼¸Î¿Ï Î½Î¯Î¿Ï Î¹Î¸ÎÎ Î¿á¼± Î´á½² á¼Î½ÏÏ Î³ÏÎ¬Î½Î¿Î½ÏÎµÏ Ïá¿Ï Î²Î¯Î²Î»Î¿Ï , Î»Î­Î³ÎµÏÎµÎ á½ Î¸Îµá½¸Ï Î¼Î±ÎºÎ±ÏÎ¯ÏÎ· ÎºÎ±á½¶ á¼Î½Î±ÏÎ±ÏÏá¿ Ïá½´Î½ ÏÏ ÏÎ®Î½ ÏÎ¿Ï á¼¸Î³Î½Î¬ÏÎ¹Îµ.

support.material:
ff. [ii]-160 Western paper, folded in folio.
Watermarks:
f. 1 Pilgrim in a circle; under the circle letters I R (?) I
( 60 48 ), in the centre of the leaf, comparable, with differences, to Sosower PÃ¨lerin 21-22, dated to 1570 and 1570-1571.
ff. 2-80, 87-88, 95-136 Hand surmounted by a flower with 5 petals; on the palm letters T (?) M
( 115 35 ), in the centre of the leaf, comparable to Sosower Main 6, which shows different letters, dated to ca. 1570.
ff. 81-86, 89-94, 137-160 Anchor in a circle surmounted by a six-point star; countermark in the centre of the leaf S T with a clover ( 65 37 ), in the centre of the leaf, comparable to Sosower Ancre 94, dated to ca. 1562.

collation.p: Part I of the manuscript is formed by 19 quaternions.
collation.signatures: Quire signatures in Greek numerals by the hand of the scribe, on the lower margin, right, of the first folio recto of each quire, original to the production of the manuscript: from Î±Î (1, f. 1r) to ÎºÎ (20, f. 153r). The 7th quire (signature Î¶Î) is missing.

supportDesc.condition: The leaves are yellowed; many water stains and brown stains are present on them. The red ink has faded on ff. 1r-104v and ff. 113r-120v.

handNote.p: ff. 1r-160v Hand A: the text has been written by the scribe Ignatios (á¼¸Î³Î½Î¬ÏÎ¹Î¿Ï, RGK I, 151) in a minuscule script, small and fairly regular, vertical, sometimes slanting lightly to the right.
The text is written in black ink; titles and initials in red.

ff. [ii] recto-160v Hand a: a contemporary or slightly later hand wrÎ¿te numerous annotations in the margins (see e.g. ff. 46r, 112v, 151r, 159r). It is a minuscule script slanting to the right, rapid. The ink is brown.
f. [ii] recto Hand b: another contemporary or slightly later hand, nervous, vertical, rapid, has written a text on f. [ii] recto, in black ink (see Additions).

decoDesc.decoNote:
Some friezes are traced at the beginning of the texts:
f. 1r plaited interlace in brown ink surmounted by a rhombus filled with a plaited motif
f. 11r chain motif surmounted by a knot
f. 14r rope motif in brown ink, partially coloured in red; over it a cross in rope motif, coloured in red.
Small friezes in red ink are present at the beginning of texts or chapters throughout this part. They show various patterns, e.g.:
f. 27[a]r knots and ropes
f. 43r ropes and plaited motifs.
Initials in ekthesis in red ink decorated with a vegetal motif on ff. 14r and f. 126r.
Red thick initials in red ink, in ekthesis, see e.g. f. 109r. The ink has faded on many leaves, see e.g. f. 39v.

additions.p:
On f. [ii] recto there is a long annotation by hand b, who copied there the question 4 from
Theodore Balsamon (12th century) Balsamon, Theodore, active 12th century
Responsa ad interrogatione Marci (PG 119, 1036 C 10-1037 B).
On f. [ii] recto, another hand wrote notes indicating subjects contained in the texts with the indication of the corresponding leaf of the manuscript.

On f. [ii] verso there is a note dated 1650 by Edward Abbot, donating the manuscript to Nicholas Hobart (see Provenance). On the lower part of the leaf is glued a paper strip with a note attesting the donation of the manuscript by Nicholas Hobart to the University Library in 1655 (see Acquisition).

origin.p: This part of the manuscript was copied by the scribe Ignatios on 19th June 1574, as stated in the colophon written by him on f. 160v.

msItem.title: Index of subjects in the Scripture
msItem.rubric: f. 161r Î Î¯Î½Î±Î¾ á¼ÎºÏÎ¹Î²á½´Ï Ïá¿¶Î½ á½ÏÎ¿Î¸Î­ÏÎµÏÎ½ Ïá¿Ï Î¸ÎµÎ¯Î±Ï Î³ÏÎ±Ïá¿Ï
msItem.incipit: f. 161r á¼ÏÏá½´ Ïá¿¶Î½ á¼Î½ Ïá¿· Î²Î¹Î²Î»Î¯á¿³ ÎÎµÎ½Î­ÏÎµÏÏ á½ÏÎ¿Î¸Î­ÏÎµÏÎ½. Î ÎµÏá½¶ Ïá¿Ï Î³ÎµÎ½Î­ÏÎµÏÏ Î¿á½ÏÎ±Î½Î¿á¿¦ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î³á¿Ï ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ïá¿¶Î½ á¼Î½ Î±á½ÏÎ¿á¿Ï ÎºÎµÏÎ¬Î»Î±Î¹Î¿Î½ Î±Î
msItem.explicit: f. 185v Î ÎµÏá½¶ Ïá¿¶Î½ ÏÏÎ±Î»Î­Î½ÏÏÎ½ ÏÏ Î¼Î¼Î¬ÏÏÎ½ Ïá¿· ÎÎ·Î¼Î·ÏÏÎ¯á¿³
msItem.note: The text ends with the first book of Maccabees

support.material:
ff. 161-185 Western paper, folded in folio.
Watermark:
Anchor in a circle surmounted by a quatrefoil; countermark in the corner of the leaf I (?) S with a clover ( 65 37 ), in the centre of the leaf, no parallels found in the main repertoires.

collation.p: Part II is formed by 1 quaternion and 3 ternions. In the last quire the last leaf is missing, without loss of text.

list.item: Quire 23 6-1 ff. 181-185(6th leaf is missing, no loss of text)

supportDesc.condition: The leaves are yellowed. The ink smudged leaving black stains, see e.g. ff. 172v-173r, ff. 178v-179r.

handNote.p: ff. 161r-185v Hand B: a minuscule script slanting to the right, nervous, characterized by a slight chiaroscuro effect, datable to the 16th c.
The text is written in black ink, initials in red.

decoDesc.decoNote:
Small friezes before or around titles, in black ink. They show various patterns, e.g.:
f. 180r ropes, sometimes coloured in red, see f. 162r
f. 179r vegetal motifs.
Red thick initials in red ink, in ekthesis, see e.g. f. 161r.

additions.p: On ff. 161v and 181r there are two marginal notes by hand a (see part I).

origin.p: This part of the manuscript was copied by an anonymous hand, probably contemporary to Ignatios, who wrote the first part, in the 16th c..
